page.title: 1.14.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
Lesson Narrative

This lesson first reviews proportions and proportional relationships to segue into variation. Students will learn how to recognize direct variation situations. They will set up direct variation equations and work to find the constant of variation to apply the direct variation equation to solve problems.

In applications using direct variation, students will know the values of one pair of the variables and will be asked to find the equation that relates \( x \) and \( y \). Then they can use that equation to find values of \( y \) for other values of \( x \).

Learning Goals (Teacher Facing)

Students will be able to:
  • Identify variables and set up a direct variation proportion, given a description of a situation.
  • Solve a direct variation proportion.

Learning Targets (Student Facing)

  • Set up and solve direct variation problems.

Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS)

TEKS

Explanation of Coverage

A2(D) write and solve equations involving direct variation; 

Full coverage: Lesson provides content that covers all parts of this TEKS.

A2(C) write linear equations in two variables given a table of values, a graph, and a verbal description.

Partial coverage: Lesson provides content that covers part of this TEKS. The parts that are covered have been underlined.

Lesson Activities

  • 1.14.0: Lesson Overview
  • 1.14.1: Solving Proportions
  • 1.14.2: Modeling Equations Using Direct Variation
    • 1.14.2: Self Check
    • 1.14.2: Additional Resources
  • 1.14.3: Using Direct Variation to Solve Application Problems, Part 1
    • 1.14.3: Self Check
    • 1.14.3: Additional Resources
  • 1.14.4: Using Direct Variation to Solve Application Problems, Part 2
  • 1.14.5: Practice
  • 1.14.6: Lesson Summary

Students will also complete a series of problems in the 1.14.5: Practice.

Required Materials

  • N/A

Required Preparation

  • N/A

Lesson Vocabulary

During this lesson, it is important to:

  • Familiarize students with the vocabulary words they will see throughout the lesson. Encourage students to look for these words and notice their use and meanings.
  • Encourage students to use key vocabulary words in “math talk” and their written and oral explanations.
  • Utilize a word wall. Sample cards are located here: Mathematics Vocabulary Word Wall Cards

Vocabulary words that are emphasized in this lesson include:

Previous Vocabulary:

  • equation
  • expression
  • proportion
  • variable

New Vocabulary:

  • direct variation
  • rational expression

    Support for Building Character

    Throughout this unit, find ways to encourage and support students to work on cultivating their social intelligence. 

    Here are some tips to try during this lesson:

    • How to Be Supportive
    • The Key to Reading People

    You can find other tips located here in the Playbook on Social Intelligence from Character Lab.

page.title: 1.14.1: Solving Proportions
page.contents:
Warm Up (5 minute)

The purpose of this warm-up is to help students recall what a proportion is and how to solve a proportion. Elicit student strategies, such as scaling up/down numerators and denominators, and if students don’t bring up cross-multiplication on their own, make sure to cover that strategy.

Launch

Remind students that they may have learned more than one way to solve these equations, and it is okay to use a variety of strategies.

Student Facing Statement

Solve each of the following proportions:

  1. \( \frac{x}{56} = \frac{7}{8} \)
  2. \( \frac{56}{72} = \frac{y}{9} \)
  3. \( \frac{98}{134} = \frac{-7}{p} \)

Student Response

  1. \( x=49 \) 
  2. \( y=7 \)
  3. \( p= -11 \)

Activity Synthesis

  • Show different work examples. Who used cross-multiplication? Who used their multiplication facts to find the missing value?
  • Can you think of situations in real life where you use proportions?

page.title: 1.14.2: Modeling Equations Using Direct Variation
page.contents:
Activity (20 minutes)

In this activity, students will work in a jigsaw format to solve a problem. They will then explain to members of other groups how they solved their problem. Facilitate a discussion after the activity where students describe their methods. Work to lead them into the relationship between the variables they used and how this is direct variation. The students will then work to solve their problem using the steps to writing a direct variation equation.

Launch

Have students work in groups of 2-3. Assign each group a problem (either 1, 2, OR 3). After the groups work through their problem, match one person from group 1, 2, and 3 together to form another group. They will then teach the new group their problem.

Student-Facing Statement

In your group, work through your assigned problem. Then be ready to share.

Group 1. When Raoul runs on the treadmill at the gym, the number of calories, \( c \), he burns varies directly with the number of minutes, \( m \), he uses the treadmill. He burned 315 calories when he used the treadmill for 18 minutes. Write the equation that relates \( c \) and \( m \). 

Group 2. The number of calories, \( c \), burned varies directly with the amount of time, \( t \), spent exercising. Arnold burned 312 calories in 65 minutes exercising. Write the equation that relates \( c \) and \( t \).

Group 3. The distance a moving body travels, \( d \), varies directly with time, \( t \), it moves. A train travels 100 miles in 2 hours. Write the equation that relates \( d \) and \( t \).

What is Direct Variation?

All of these are examples of direct variation.

Two variables vary directly if one is the product of a constant and the other.

For any two variables x and \( y \), \( y \) varies directly with \( x \) if 

\( y=kx \), where \( k≠0 \)

The constant k is called the constant of variation.

Look back at the problem you solved. Use the direct variation equation to solve it again using these steps:


Step 1

Write the equation for direct variation.

Step 2

Substitute the given values for the variables.

Step 3

Solve for the constant of variation.

Step 4

Write the equation that relates x and y using the constant of variation.

Let’s look at example 3 again and solve it with the direct variation equation.

The distance a moving body travels, \( d \), varies directly with time, \( t \), it moves. A train travels 100 miles in 2 hours. Write the equation that relates \( d \) and \( t \).




Step 1

Write the equation for direct variation.

\( y = kx \)

Step 2

Substitute the given values for the variables.

\( 100 = k(2) \)

Step 3

Solve for the constant of variation.

\( k=50 \)

Step 4

Write the equation that relates x and y using the constant of variation.

\( y =50x \)

Student Response

  • Group 1: c=17.5m
  • Group 2: c = 4.8 m
  • Group 3: d= 50t

Anticipated Misconceptions

Make sure students understand the concept of input and output and the independent variable and dependent variable. Students will commonly switch the values that are substituted for \( x \) and \( y \) in the equation, which will result in an incorrect value for \( k \).


1.14.2: Self Check

Following the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.


QUESTION: 

The price, \( P \), that Eric pays for gas varies directly with the number of gallons, \( g \), he buys. It costs him $65 to buy 25 gallons of gas. Which equation expresses the price of any amount of gas, \( P \), in terms of the number of gallons \( g \)?

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

\( P= \frac{13}{5} g \)

That’s correct! Check yourself: Use the direct variation equation, \( y=kx \). Substitute to find \( k \), 65=k(25). Now, \( k=6525=135 \). So, the equation is \( P=135g \).

\( P=25g \)

Incorrect. This is the equation if each gallon was $25. Let’s try again a different way: Use the direct variation equation, 

\( y=kx \). Substitute to find \( k \), \( 65=k(25) \). Now, \( k=6525=135 \). The answer is \( P=135g \). 

\( P= \frac{65}{g} \)

Incorrect. This is the equation if Eric wants to find the cost per a certain number of gallons that is not known. Let’s try again a different way: Use the direct variation equation, 

\( y=kx \). Substitute to find \( k \), \( 65=k(25) \). Now, \( k=6525=135 \). The answer is \( P=135g \).

\( P= \frac{5}{13}g \)

Incorrect. Make sure that you solve for \( k \) correctly. Let’s try again a different way: Use the direct variation equation, 

\( y=kx \). Substitute to find \( k \), \( 65=k(25) \). Now, \( k= \frac{65}{25} = \frac{13}{5} \). The answer is \( P= \frac{13}{5}g \). 

1.14.2: Self Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it.

Modeling Situations Using Direct Variation

When two quantities are related by a proportion, we say they are proportional to each other. Another way to express this relation is to talk about the variation of the two quantities. We will discuss direct variation here.

Lindsay gets paid $15 per hour at her job. If we let s be her salary, in dollars per hour, and h be the number of hours she has worked, we could model this situation with the equation

\( \( s=15h \) \)

Lindsay’s salary is the product of a constant, 15, and the number of hours she works. We say that Lindsay’s salary varies directly with the number of hours she works. Two variables vary directly if one is the product of a constant and the other.


Direct Variation

For any two variables \( x \) and \( x \), y varies directly with \( x \) if 

\( y=kx \), where \( k≠0 \)

The constant \( k \) is called the constant of variation.

In applications using direct variation, generally we will know values of one pair of the variables and will be asked to find the equation that relates \( x \) and \( y \). 

Here’s how to model an equation using direct variation for application problems.


Step 1

Write the formula for direct variation.

Step 2

Substitute the given values for the variables.

Step 3

Solve for the constant of variation.

Step 4

Write the equation that relates x and y using the constant of variation.


Let’s look at an application problem:

The cost of a pizza, \( y \), varies directly with its diameter, \( x \), and an 8-inch pizza costs $12. What is the equation that relates \( x \) and \( y \)?


Step 1

Write the formula for direct variation.

\( y = kx \)

Step 2

Substitute the given values for the variables.

\( 12 = k(8) \)

Step 3

Solve for the constant of variation.

\( k= \frac{12}{8}= \frac{3}{2} \)

Step 4

Write the equation that relates x and y using the constant of variation.


Try It: Modeling Situations Using Direct Variation

The distance a moving body travels, \( d \), varies directly with time, \( t \), it moves. A train travels 60 miles in 2 hours.

What is the equation that relates \( d \) and \( t \)?

Write down your answer, then select the Solution button to check your work.

Solution

Here is how to do this application problem of direct variation:


Step 1

Write the formula for direct variation.

\( y = kx \)

\( d=kt \)

Step 2

Identify the variables

d: distance, t: time

Step 3

Substitute the given values for the variables.

\( 60 = k(2) \)

Step 4

Solve for the constant of variation, \( k \).

\( k=30 \)

Step 5

Write the equation that relates d and \( t \) using the constant of variation.

\( d=30t \)


How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

page.title: 1.14.3: Using Direct Variation to Solve Application Problems, Part 1
page.contents:
Activity (20 minutes)

This activity prompts students to use the equations from activity 1.14.2 to find an answer to a question involving their situation. Students will find how many calories are burned on a treadmill and how far a train travels in a set amount of time.

Launch

While students are working, be sure to circulate to make sure that groups are entering the correct values in equations. Ask questions like “is that value the input or the output?” And, “which variable represents the input in your equation.” After the activity, there is a video that will help struggling students solve direct variation problems. Finally, if there is extra time, have groups create another question from their given situation and give it to another group to solve it!

Student-Facing Statement 

Return to your original group and work through this next part of your assigned problem. Then be ready to share. 

  1. When Raoul runs on the treadmill at the gym, the number of calories, c, he burns varies directly with the number of minutes, m, he uses the treadmill. He burned 315 calories when he used the treadmill for 18 minutes. 
    • How many calories would he burn if he ran on the treadmill for 25 minutes?
  2. The number of calories, c, burned varies directly with the amount of time, t, spent exercising. Arnold burned 312 calories in 65 minutes exercising. 
    • >How many calories would he burn if he exercises for 90 minutes?
  3. The distance a moving body travels, d, varies directly with time, t, it moves. A train travels 100 miles in 2 hours.

How many miles would it travel in 5 hours?

Video: Using Direct Variation to Solve Application Problems

Watch the following video to learn more about how to use direct variation to solve an application problem.


Student Response

  1. c=437.5, so Raoul would burn 437.5 calories if he used the treadmill for 25 minutes
  2. c=432
  3. 250 miles

Student-Facing Extension

Are you ready for more?

For example 1, how could you find out how many minutes Raoul would need to use the treadmill to burn a certain amount of calories?

Extension Student Response

Sample response: Substitute the number of calories you want to burn into the equation for \( c \), then solve for \( t \).

1.14.3: Self Check

Following the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.


QUESTION: 

Sophia is making parts for a model ship. The number of parts, p, she can make in a day varies directly with the number of hours, h, she works. She can make 28 parts in 4 hours. How many parts would Sophia make in 9 hours?

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

63 

That’s correct! Check yourself: The constant of variation is \( \frac{28}{4}=7 \). The equation is now \( p=7h \). After 9 hours, Sophia makes 63 parts.

16

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Remember to use multiplication in direct variation. The correct answer is 63 parts. 

79

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Recall that when multiplying to use parentheses and multiply. The correct answer is 63 parts. 

252

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Make sure to find the constant of variation before substituting into the equation. The correct answer is 63 parts. 


1.14.3: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it.

1.14.3: Solve Application Problems Using Direct Variation

In applications using direct variation, generally we will know values of one pair of the variables and will be asked to find the equation that relates \( x \) and \( y \). Then we can use that equation to find values of \( y \) for other values of \( x \).

Here’s how to solve applications of direct variation problems.


Step 1

Write the equation for direct variation.

Step 2

Identify the variables.

Step 3

Substitute the given values for the variables.

Step 4

Solve for the constant of variation.

Step 5

Write the equation that relates x and y using the constant of variation.

Step 6

Substitute the value for the variable.

Step 7

Solve.

Let’s look at an application problem:

If the cost of a pizza varies directly with its diameter, and an 8-inch pizza costs $12, how much would a 6-inch pizza cost?


Step 1

Write the equation for direct variation.

\( y = kx \)

Step 2

Identify the variables.

y: cost of pizza, x: diameter

Step 3

Substitute the given values for the variables.

12 = k(8)

Step 4

Solve for the constant of variation.

Step 5

Write the equation that relates x and y using the constant of variation.

\( y= \frac{3}{2}x \)

Step 6

Substitute the value for the variable.

\( y= \frac{3}{2}(6) \)

Step 7

Solve.

\( y = 9 \)


What does this mean in the context of the problem?

A pizza that has a diameter of 6 inches costs $9.

Try It: Solve Application Problems Using Direct Variation

The number of buckets of water, b, filled by a spring varies directly with the number of minutes, m, passed. The spring fills 3 buckets of water in 14 minutes.

How many buckets would be filled in 42 minutes?

Write down your answer, then select the Solution button to check your work.

Solution

Here is how to this application problem of direct variation:


Step 1

Write the formula for direct variation.

\( y = kx \)

\( b=km \)

Step 2

Identify the variables.

b: number of buckets, m: number of minutes

Step 3

Substitute the given values for the variables.

\( 3=k(14) \)

Step 4

Solve for the constant of variation.

\( k= 3/14 \)

Step 5

Write the equation that relates m and b using the constant of variation.

\( b= \frac{3}{14}m \)

Step 6

Substitute the value for the variable.

\( b= \frac{3}{14}(42) \)

Step 7

Solve.

b= 9 buckets

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

page.title: 1.14.4: Using Direct Variation to Solve Application Problems, Part 2
page.contents:
Cool Down (5 minutes)


Student Facing Statement

Jesse’s car gets 30 miles per gallon of gas.

  1. Write an equation using direct variation for distance, d, and number of gallons of gas, g for this problem.
  2. If Jesse travels 150 miles he uses 5 gallons of gas. Find the constant of variation.
  3. Now, write the equation if Jesse travels d miles with a car that uses 30 miles per gallon of gas.
  4. If Las Vegas is 285 miles away, how many gallons of gas are needed to get there?

Student Response

  1. Use the equation for direct variation \( y=kx \). So, \( d=kg \).
  2. Use the equation for direct variation \( y=kx \). So, 150=k(5). The constant of variation is \( k=30 \).
  3. \( d=30g \)
  4. Substitute 285 miles in for m in the equation. So, \( d=30(285)=8,550 \).

Response to Student Thinking

More Chances

Students will have more opportunities to understand the mathematical ideas in this cool-down, so there is no need to slow down or add additional work to the next lessons. Instead, use the results of this cool-down to provide guidance for what to look for and emphasize over the next several lessons to support students in advancing their current understanding.

page.title: 1.14.5: Practice
page.contents:
Students will complete the following questions to practice the skills they have learned in this lesson.

  1. If \( y \) varies directly as \( x \) and \( y=14 \),​ when \( x=3 \). find the equation that relates \( x \) and \( y \).

    1. \(x=\frac{14}3y\)
    2. \(y=\frac3{14}x\)
    3. \(3x=14y\)
    4. \(y=\frac{14}3x\)

    ANSWER:       \( y= \frac{14}{3}x \)

  2. The price, \( P \), that Eric pays for gas varies directly with the number of gallons, \( g \), he buys. It costs him $50 to buy 20 gallons of gas.

    Choose the equation that relates \(P\) and \(g\).

    1. \(P=2.5\)
    2. \(P=\frac{2.5}g\)
    3. \(g=\frac{2.5}P\)
    4. \(P=\frac g{2.5}\)

    ANSWER: \(P= 2.5g\)
  3. Joseph is traveling on a road trip. The distance, \( d \), he travels before stopping for lunch varies directly with the speed, \( v \), he travels. He can travel 120 miles at a speed of 60 mph. How many miles would he travel before stopping for lunch at a rate of 65 mph? Only enter integers.

    ANSWER:     130


  4. The mass of a liquid, \( M \), varies directly with its volume, \( V \). A liquid with mass 16 kilograms has a volume of 2 liters. 

    What is the volume, in liters, of this liquid if its mass is 128 kilograms? Enter integers only.

    ANSWER:      16

  5. The length, \( L \), that a spring stretches varies directly with a weight, \( W \), placed at the end of the spring. When Sarah placed a 10-pound watermelon on a hanging scale, the spring stretched 5 inches.

    What weight of watermelon, in pounds, would stretch the spring 6 inches? Enter integers only.

    ANSWER: 12


  6. The maximum load a beam, \( M \), will support varies directly with the square of the diagonal of the beam’s cross-section, \( d^2 \). A beam with diagonal 6 inch will support a maximum load of 108 pounds. 

    What load, in pounds, will a beam with a 10-inch diagonal support? Enter integers only.

    ANSWER: 300

  7. The number of calories, \( c \), burned varies directly with the amount of time, \( t \), spent exercising. Arnold burned 312 calories in 65 minutes exercising. 

    How many calories would he burn if he exercises for 90 minutes? Enter integers only.

    ANSWER: 432

page.title: 1.14.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
Some key takeaways from this lesson are the ideas that real-life situations often vary directly. Direct variation problems use a constant of variation. They can be used not only to find the output, but also the input.

To help students see these points, discuss questions such as:

  • Could you use direct variation equations if you had the output and had to find the input?
  • For example 1, how many minutes would Raoul have to use the treadmill to burn 500 calories?
  • For example 2, how many minutes would Arnold have exercise to burn 500 calories?
  • For example 3, how long would it take the train to go 800 miles?

Tell students that equations are mathematical models. A model is a mathematical representation of a real-life situation. When people create models, they rely on the information they have, but they also make assumptions and decisions that affect the models. If the information or assumptions change, the model would also change.

To continue to the student-facing version of this lesson, select “1.14: Direct Variation” below.
